Do we really want to get into the business of programmatically determining the home dashboard for users?  This relies heavily on an API that can drastically change between major versions, and it also requires knowing the numerical ID of the desired dashboard to star as the "favorite" (read: home dashboard).  I think we should leave this explicitly to users to handle on their own, whether through the GUI as the organization administrator or programmatically external to the chart'}, {'account_id': 30582, 'date': '2020-02-13 17:25:32.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Change of direction to create this downstream.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2020-02-17 18:47:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Do we really want to get into the business of programmatically
 > determining the home dashboard for users?  This relies heavily on
 > an API that can drastically change between major versions, and it
 > also requires knowing the numerical ID of the desired dashboard to
 > star as the "favorite" (read: home dashboard).  I think we should
 > leave this explicitly to users to handle on their own, whether
 > through the GUI as the organization administrator or
 > programmatically external to the chart

I think though less than ideal, we should support this - and within the chart is the correct place to do so.'}, {'account_id': 30582, 'date': '2020-02-17 18:49:53.000000000', 'content': 'Restored

Back to using charts for this change'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2020-02-17 19:01:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> > Do we really want to get into the business of programmatically
 > > determining the home dashboard for users?  This relies heavily on
 > > an API that can drastically change between major versions, and it
 > > also requires knowing the numerical ID of the desired dashboard
 > to
 > > star as the "favorite" (read: home dashboard).  I think we should
 > > leave this explicitly to users to handle on their own, whether
 > > through the GUI as the organization administrator or
 > > programmatically external to the chart
 > 
 > I think though less than ideal, we should support this - and within
 > the chart is the correct place to do so.

At the moment, this implementation is very opinionated in that it assumes any user is part of the organization for whatever home dashboard is being defined.  That's not guaranteed to be the case.  That's why I don't really care for handling this in the chart in this manner.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2020-02-18 00:18:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> > > Do we really want to get into the business of programmatically
 > > > determining the home dashboard for users?  This relies heavily

 > within

 > At the moment, this implementation is very opinionated in that it
 > assumes any user is part of the organization for whatever home
 > dashboard is being defined.  That's not guaranteed to be the case. 
 > That's why I don't really care for handling this in the chart in
 > this manner.

This should undoubtedly be made optional, but I think it is somewhat unlikely that as is this chart would be used as is to support multiple organizations. It's a fantastic goal to have but would require significant enhancement to various aspects of this deployment, which go far beyond an opinionated welcome screens scope.'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2020-02-18 00:41:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 30777, 'date': '2020-02-18 20:35:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 30777, 'date': '2020-02-18 22:36:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

commit_message:
Grafana: Provision to add customized HomePage

This code will help to add any customized dashboard as a Home Page for
Grafana. The add_home_dashboard script will be executed after the
Grafana is deployed which sets a new Dashboard(OSH Home) as a landing
Page for a specific Organization.

Change-Id: I32b6b9cad4eaefe7d153cae797d3b3143be5c49b

commit_message:
Handle package builds when testing in rdoinfo

rdoinfo is branchless and to test reviews under
non-master branches, we need to treat rdoinfo
specially.

Also use zuul.override_checkout if defined to build
zuul_deps.

Change-Id: I44353e7308d2eab56e986d0f2f6fb3a80a25b227

Do not release monasca-log-api for Ussuri

releses of this service for new OpenStack versions. The repository will
be used only for maintaining stable branches.

messages: [{'account_id': 8064, 'date': '2020-03-03 03:12:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-03-03 21:41:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-03-04 00:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-03 03:12:08.000000000', 'message': 'Fix: use stein version of modules instead of train

In commit 69b547995f5f07a7c55f3a0a2c524b21b313d1ef, the cherry-pick
mistakenly updated openstacklib and vswitch modules to train versions.

Downgrading them to stein versions. The only additional module needed
with the cherry pick is an include ovs::dpdk, which is already in stein,
so this is fine.

Change-Id: I58e2db75ba872c31b96d87e0928ddc62198b68d4
'}]
commit_message:
Fix: use stein version of modules instead of train

In commit 69b547995f5f07a7c55f3a0a2c524b21b313d1ef, the cherry-pick
mistakenly updated openstacklib and vswitch modules to train versions.

Downgrading them to stein versions. The only additional module needed
with the cherry pick is an include ovs::dpdk, which is already in stein,
so this is fine.

Change-Id: I58e2db75ba872c31b96d87e0928ddc62198b68d4

subject: Switch neutron-*-dashboard to cycle-with-rc
messages:
[{'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-02-25 22:04:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-02-28 11:42:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

The rationale behind these changes make sense.

LGTM only +1 for now by waiting for PLT/liaison/team approval.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2020-02-28 11:44:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

looking how low is development on those projects, I'm ok with this change."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-02-28 15:20:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I am okay with this change. These dashboard development activities are pretty low. I originally thought we have one or ZERO releases required when we split out these from horizon, but having stable branches sounds a good approach at that time. That's the only reason I chose cycle-with-intermediary. I see no reasonable differences in cycle-with-intermediary and cycle-with-rc now considering the activity on these dashboards."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-03-04 00:34:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

> I am okay with this change. These dashboard development activities
 > are pretty low. I originally thought we have one or ZERO releases
 > required when we split out these from horizon, but having stable
 > branches sounds a good approach at that time. That's the only
 > reason I chose cycle-with-intermediary. I see no reasonable
 > differences in cycle-with-intermediary and cycle-with-rc now
 > considering the activity on these dashboards.

Another option would be to move to independent. That sounds like maybe what you might actually need. If a release isn't tied to a cycle, and if it could happen whenever there is actually something the team wants to get out there, independent would make it easier for that.

Going to approve this, but if you do end up wanting to move to independent, we can switch that later."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-25 22:04:34.000000000', 'message': 'Switch neutron-*-dashboard to cycle-with-rc

Deliverables following the cycle-with-intermediary model are expected
to release multiple times throughout the development cycle. Since
neutron-*-dashboard only released once last cycle, and has not done a release
yet this cycle, this proposes changing the release model to cycle-with-rc
so the expectation is only that it will release an RC by the end of
the cycle prior to doing the final release.

For the team, please respond to this patch in one of the following ways:

* -1 this patch and follow up with an intermediary release
* +1 this patch and we will switch over the release model
* -1 this patch, but acknowledge a release will be done prior to the
  RC1 deadline.

Change-Id: I6962e9c710dd6c5cc5f31d9e75121aa22188bce6
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Switch neutron-*-dashboard to cycle-with-rc

Deliverables following the cycle-with-intermediary model are expected
to release multiple times throughout the development cycle. Since
neutron-*-dashboard only released once last cycle, and has not done a release
yet this cycle, this proposes changing the release model to cycle-with-rc
so the expectation is only that it will release an RC by the end of
the cycle prior to doing the final release.

For the team, please respond to this patch in one of the following ways:

* -1 this patch and follow up with an intermediary release
* +1 this patch and we will switch over the release model
* -1 this patch, but acknowledge a release will be done prior to the
  RC1 deadline.

Change-Id: I6962e9c710dd6c5cc5f31d9e75121aa22188bce6
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add an additional validation to check ceph-ansible repository

In order to address the ceph-ansible potential cross-shipping,
this change adds an extra task to validate the repository that
should be used to install ceph-ansible in the undercloud.
If ceph-ansible is not installed or the repo doesn't match the
specified one, this validation raise an error.

Change-Id: Ib80b55cbd0d4b4dd83d8dbc9dc2afe1d6df2ede5
Closes-Bug: 1857460
(cherry picked from commit 329f740d109b87105eac36fade70c69c15781a38)

commit_message:
Set Victoria  configuration

Based on the email thread back in December, we settled roughly
on a set of dates, but concluded we should bump them back
an extra week so that PTL elections can be concluded before
we open the Victoria master branch. The necessary
TC charter changes to update term lengths have also been
made.

Change-Id: I66872e55b31319a00cfee795898f2990dfc87fe7

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-18 16:20:35.000000000', 'message': "Rename devstack service neutron-ovn-metadata-agent

... to q-ovn-metadata-agent.

To the best of my understanding we decided to keep using the
neutron-legacy devstack module since it is the one used in the gate:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-December/thread.html#11544

And we merge new features like the ovn migration only working with
neutron-legacy:

https://review.opendev.org/696592

It seems to me we were a bit inconsistent in naming devstack service
'neutron-ovn-metadata-agent' since legacy style devstack service
names start with 'q-'.

For example this sample config is broken:

https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/devstack/ovn-compute-local.conf.sample#L31-L35

stack.sh dies with:

lib/neutron: line 368: neutron_plugin_create_nova_conf: command not found

Because not having a single 'q-' service in that enabled service list
we trip up devstack's 'is_neutron_legacy_enabled' check:

https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/src/commit/e51cbf0ea9469e193473972fa5dd5b0de72d9a0e/lib/neutron#L127-L135

This change renames devstack service neutron-ovn-metadata-agent
to q-ovn-metadata-agent.

I'm not proud to propose this change in 2020 (circa 5 years after
the rename from Quantum to Neutron) so let me know if you see a better
way. :-)

Change-Id: I507a3426e2b63bff49891bd5a51fa9d9999a0ffa

commit_message:
Rename devstack service neutron-ovn-metadata-agent

... to q-ovn-metadata-agent.

To the best of my understanding we decided to keep using the
neutron-legacy devstack module since it is the one used in the gate:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-December/thread.html#11544

And we merge new features like the ovn migration only working with
neutron-legacy:

https://review.opendev.org/696592

It seems to me we were a bit inconsistent in naming devstack service
'neutron-ovn-metadata-agent' since legacy style devstack service
names start with 'q-'.

For example this sample config is broken:

https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/devstack/ovn-compute-local.conf.sample#L31-L35

stack.sh dies with:

lib/neutron: line 368: neutron_plugin_create_nova_conf: command not found

Because not having a single 'q-' service in that enabled service list
we trip up devstack's 'is_neutron_legacy_enabled' check:

https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/src/commit/e51cbf0ea9469e193473972fa5dd5b0de72d9a0e/lib/neutron#L127-L135

This change renames devstack service neutron-ovn-metadata-agent
to q-ovn-metadata-agent.

I'm not proud to propose this change in 2020 (circa 5 years after
the rename from Quantum to Neutron) so let me know if you see a better
way. :-)

Change-Id: I507a3426e2b63bff49891bd5a51fa9d9999a0ffa

Fix copypaste errors in access rule command

Access rules are access rules, not application credentials.

Change-Id: I74d05f11ec186283e5a86d92dcbfe4eb24130eee

[{'created': '2020-02-25 20:59:28.000000000', 'message': 'Cinder backup export broken

Incremental patch I516b7c82b05b26e81195f7f106d43a9e0804082d
introduced a regression, breaking the volume backup export
functionality.

Apparently, the newly introduced "parent" db field isn't
serialized properly.

This is the traceback from the launchpad bug:
oslo_versionedobjects.exception.ObjectActionError:
Object action obj_load_attr failed because: attribute
parent not lazy-loadable

Looking at the traceback, and the Backup OVO code it seems
like we have 2 problems:

- We don't support lazy loading the parent
- We try to serialize the parent

Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I017602353e96cf9f0922074f94276002b17d1359
Closes-Bug: #1862635
(cherry picked from commit a98969380ac2172766995cf02b889e3c863511ba)
modified:
cinder/tests/unit/objects/test_backup.py - pyflake issue #202

commit_message:
Cinder backup export broken

Incremental patch I516b7c82b05b26e81195f7f106d43a9e0804082d
introduced a regression, breaking the volume backup export
functionality.

Apparently, the newly introduced "parent" db field isn't
serialized properly.

This is the traceback from the launchpad bug:
oslo_versionedobjects.exception.ObjectActionError:
Object action obj_load_attr failed because: attribute
parent not lazy-loadable

Looking at the traceback, and the Backup OVO code it seems
like we have 2 problems:

- We don't support lazy loading the parent
- We try to serialize the parent

Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I017602353e96cf9f0922074f94276002b17d1359
Closes-Bug: #1862635
(cherry picked from commit a98969380ac2172766995cf02b889e3c863511ba)
modified:
cinder/tests/unit/objects/test_backup.py - pyflake issue #202
(cherry picked from commit 6dfbec7f7403bbbe498c5eaba16b5b68bd7d698c)

Add is_sort_key for vpnaas attribute maps

Add 'is_sort_key' for base vpnaas resources attribute:
vpnservices, ipsec_site_connections, ipsecpolicies, ikepolicies.

commit_message:
Add raid configuration playbook and options

This change adds the baremetal raid configuration option to the
os_baremetal_clean_node module. This was added here because
cleaning has a direct connection to raid configuration within the
API and CLI so it makes sense to couple these things within the
same module. The module will now handle the raid_config option
and apply the configuration to all node_uuid(s) provided prior
to running a cleaning event.

Story: 2007212
Task: 38449

Change-Id: I51b1977b53995c93eb661f9ffa6d7cbad033ab75
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Implement concurrency in baremetal cleaning

This change implements the concurrency functionality in the os_baremetal_clean_node
module. The module will now process all nodes provided concurently limiting threads
to the number of nodes or the option `concurrency` which has a default of 20. If the
number of nodes less that value of `concurrency` the thread pool will be limited
to the number of nodes.

Change-Id: I07f3c731c79cfe9bac8652f082e291832dc9b351
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add HSM ansible-roles to Ussuri

This patch adds two ansible role repos missing from the Ussuri
deliverables:

- ansible-role-atos-hsm
- ansible-role-thales-hsm

These are both official repos co-owned by the openstack-ansible
and barbican teams.

Change-Id: I50420096275e10ec8810094d49b864151dcdcb4c

commit_message:
Remove 'nova.image.api' module

This doesn't exist for 'nova.volume' and no longer exists for
'nova.network'. There's only one image backend we support, so do like
we've done elsewhere and just use 'nova.image.glance'.

Change-Id: I7ca7d8a92dfbc7c8d0ee2f9e660eabaa7e220e2a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

This change modifies the provide playbook to simply require the uuids of nodes
to be provided instead of attempting to discover managable nodes. This will

commit_message:
Modify the provide playbook to simplify client interactions

This change modifies the provide playbook to simply require the uuids of nodes
to be provided instead of attempting to discover managable nodes. This will
simplify client interactions while also making it clear to admins calling this
playbook directly what the inputs are and how to leverage it.

Task: 38443

Change-Id: Ic1cf39a29826b3828967e23a056884d867431062
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove extra header fields in proxied metadata requests

If a user specifies a header in their request for metadata,
it could override what the proxy would have inserted on their
behalf. Make sure to remove any headers we don't want, and
override something that might be present in the request.
If the agent somehow gets a request with both headers it will
silently drop it.

Change-Id: Id6c103b7bcebe441c27c6049d349d84ba7fd15a6
Closes-bug: #1865036

[{'created': '2020-02-26 11:41:33.000000000', 'message': 'Fix regex to correctly recognize scientific notation with QemuImgInfo

qemu 4.1.0 output shifts to scientific notation at 1000mb, breaking
oslo.utils.

Problem here is that the qemu-img output shifts to scientific notation:

999 => 999 MiB
1000 => 1e+03 MiB

The regex in python-oslo-utils does not cover this.

This issue is likely regexp parsing "disk size: 1e+03 MiB" value.

These changes fix that.

Change-Id: I4c016865890135023ceb497de18d75ccebd5961a
Closes-Bug: 1864529
(cherry picked from commit ebf8368501500767fd4e6e13602bb88950a4484b)

commit_message:
Fix regex to correctly recognize scientific notation with QemuImgInfo

qemu 4.1.0 output shifts to scientific notation at 1000mb, breaking
oslo.utils.

Problem here is that the qemu-img output shifts to scientific notation:

999 => 999 MiB
1000 => 1e+03 MiB

The regex in python-oslo-utils does not cover this.

This issue is likely regexp parsing "disk size: 1e+03 MiB" value.

These changes fix that.

Change-Id: I4c016865890135023ceb497de18d75ccebd5961a
Closes-Bug: 1864529
(cherry picked from commit ebf8368501500767fd4e6e13602bb88950a4484b)
(cherry picked from commit 85cd57d1c5b7f1e046f831b9b1caa341b688cfb4)

OK, here's what's happening with the pep8 job.

This passed master, which is using:
flake8==3.7.9
hacking==2.0.0
pyflakes==2.1.1
pycodestyle==2.5.0

But failed here in stable/train, where we have:
flake8==2.6.2
hacking==1.1.0
pyflakes==1.2.3
pycodestyle==2.5.0

The problem is that the pyflakes in stable/train (being pulled in by flake8 which is being pulled in by hacking) is subject to bug https://github.com/PyCQA/pyflakes/issues/202 which was fixed in pyflakes 2.1.0."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-02-25 14:07:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

[{'created': '2020-02-25 03:19:50.000000000', 'message': 'Cinder backup export broken

Incremental patch I516b7c82b05b26e81195f7f106d43a9e0804082d
introduced a regression, breaking the volume backup export
functionality.

Apparently, the newly introduced "parent" db field isn't
serialized properly.

This is the traceback from the launchpad bug:
oslo_versionedobjects.exception.ObjectActionError:
Object action obj_load_attr failed because: attribute
parent not lazy-loadable

Looking at the traceback, and the Backup OVO code it seems
like we have 2 problems:

- We don't support lazy loading the parent
- We try to serialize the parent

Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Cinder backup export broken

Incremental patch I516b7c82b05b26e81195f7f106d43a9e0804082d
introduced a regression, breaking the volume backup export
functionality.

Apparently, the newly introduced "parent" db field isn't
serialized properly.

This is the traceback from the launchpad bug:
oslo_versionedobjects.exception.ObjectActionError:
Object action obj_load_attr failed because: attribute
parent not lazy-loadable

Looking at the traceback, and the Backup OVO code it seems
like we have 2 problems:

- We don't support lazy loading the parent
- We try to serialize the parent

Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I017602353e96cf9f0922074f94276002b17d1359
Closes-Bug: #1862635
(cherry picked from commit a98969380ac2172766995cf02b889e3c863511ba)
modified:
cinder/tests/unit/objects/test_backup.py - pyflake issue #202

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-10 21:41:25.000000000', 'message': "Allow tags to be removed with update --existing

When updating a stack using the PATCH method (i.e. passing --existing on
the command line), the existing tags are kept unless otherwise
specified. However, while it was possible to set a new set of tags on
such an update, it was not possible to remove all of the tags because an
empty string was treated the same as None or a missing tags key (both of
which are treated as no change).

When the user explicitly requests an empty tags list (by passing ''),
honour that request.

Note that while None is treated the same as a missing key, in practice
the API never sends us a value of None; the key is never sent to the
engine if the user passes null to the API. The input string is split by
the API so the engine receives data with the key then the value is
always a Python list.

Change-Id: I6ae355b0a8af017c7a9145c9483c1ad3f2ac5ca5
Task: 37010
"}]
commit_message:
Allow tags to be removed with update --existing

When updating a stack using the PATCH method (i.e. passing --existing on
the command line), the existing tags are kept unless otherwise
specified. However, while it was possible to set a new set of tags on
such an update, it was not possible to remove all of the tags because an
empty string was treated the same as None or a missing tags key (both of
which are treated as no change).

When the user explicitly requests an empty tags list (by passing ''),
honour that request.

Note that while None is treated the same as a missing key, in practice
the API never sends us a value of None; the key is never sent to the
engine if the user passes null to the API. The input string is split by
the API so the engine receives data with the key then the value is
always a Python list.

Change-Id: I6ae355b0a8af017c7a9145c9483c1ad3f2ac5ca5
Task: 37010

commit_message:
Add GRENADE_USE_EXTERNAL_DEVSTACK to skip part of the setup

When GRENADE_USE_EXTERNAL_DEVSTACK is set to True,
the initial steps performed by grenade are skipped, namely:
- grabbing and configuring the base and the target devstacks;
- running devstacks on the base target.

This change is required to allow a native Zuul v3 job to use
the existing workflow to setup and run devstack.

Change-Id: I232db8de05141849c81851dd29440959cb0d8533

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-26 22:35:28.000000000', 'message': 'Do not force live migration outside of Availability zone

If live migration tests are ran on environment with multiple AZ and
destination host for live migration is chosen from different AZ then
nova scheduler would stop such migration and live migration tests
would fail so in the case of CONF.compute.compute_volume_common_az
being set in config file, choose destination host from the same
availability zone (the same happens with cinder AZ).

Change-Id: I6bfad96ae3aa6cd8efd7ae2a0ce01c53140f617a
'}]
commit_message:
Do not force live migration outside of Availability zone

If live migration tests are ran on environment with multiple AZ and
destination host for live migration is chosen from different AZ then
nova scheduler would stop such migration and live migration tests
would fail so in the case of CONF.compute.compute_volume_common_az
being set in config file, choose destination host from the same
availability zone (the same happens with cinder AZ).

Change-Id: I6bfad96ae3aa6cd8efd7ae2a0ce01c53140f617a

[{'created': '2020-01-09 21:08:38.000000000', 'message': "Pass the actual target in os-assisted_volume_snapshots policy

Currently if target is not passed in context.can(),
it use defauls target which is context.user_id, context.project_id.
These defaults target are not useful as it pass the
context's user_id and project_id only which means we tell
oslo policy to verify the context data with context data.

This commit pass the actual target for os-assisted_volume_snapshots
policies which is empty dict because policy rule is system scoped rather
than project, so the token scope check deals with the required
target checking.

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh

Change-Id: I38393f3042adb82fef5e038c99296c27c88ed864
"}, {'created': '2020-03-02 11:52:52.000000000', 'message': "Pass the actual target in os-assisted_volume_snapshots policy

commit_message:
Pass the actual target in os-assisted_volume_snapshots policy

Currently if target is not passed in context.can(),
it use defauls target which is context.user_id, context.project_id.
These defaults target are not useful as it pass the
context's user_id and project_id only which means we tell
oslo policy to verify the context data with context data.

This commit pass the actual target for os-assisted_volume_snapshots
policies which is empty dict because policy rule is system scoped rather
than project, so the token scope check deals with the required
target checking.

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh

Change-Id: I38393f3042adb82fef5e038c99296c27c88ed864

commit_message:
Updated from generate-constraints

hold back docutils because boto likes to cap things
hold back msgpack because salt likes to cap things
hold back alembic because it breaks nova tests
  - review.opendev.org/708707

Change-Id: I4c7b301c8be303034f3303c866f9afb199788163

Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
'}, {'created': '2020-03-02 15:41:52.000000000', 'message': '[OVN] DevStack: Split the OVN_BRANCH and OVS_BRANCH variables

We will soon have different version for OVN and OVS, this patch is

splitting the OVN_BRANCH and OVS_BRANCH variables in the DevStack
module.

commit_message:
Raise minimum SQLAlchemy version to 1.2.0

Per [1], this is the latest supported version of SQLAlchemy. 1.1.x and
earlier are EOL.

[1] https://www.sqlalchemy.org/download.html#relstatus

Change-Id: I63e4baf772be9ddfb787ac3aff01fcaddf7b901c
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Tune-up package install

This change will make the client package install process faster by skipping the
include loop which will make better use of the built-in ansible package action
plugin.

Change-Id: Ie7f241ba5b7df5aea423df5cf03930cad1c1f3eb
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
[libvirt] Use ceph image for ceph related scripts

This is to update two of init containers to use ceph confighelper image as
they are executing ceph based scripts and the image also will have latest
clients installed for ceph activities.

Change-Id: Ie4fbd8af2645d5bc5b7e4f0fd22874987a0f55f6

[{'created': '2020-02-26 12:58:37.000000000', 'message': "Throw TypeError in repository enable/disable macros

Currently we do not validate the type of the reponames argument to the
enable_extra_repos and disable_extra_repos macros. It should be a list,
but we merged a call where the argument was a string, which interpreted
as a list of single characters ('e', 'p', 'e', 'l'), and silently
ignored.

This change validates that the reponames argument is a list to avoid

Change-Id: I497c8b2c1dc548e678698474d3604664cf8eeb07
"}, {'created': '2020-02-26 13:59:36.000000000', 'message': "Throw TypeError in repository enable/disable macros

Currently we do not validate the type of the reponames argument to the
enable_extra_repos and disable_extra_repos macros. It should be a list,
but we merged a call where the argument was a string, which interpreted
as a list of single characters ('e', 'p', 'e', 'l'), and silently

This change validates that the reponames argument is a list to avoid
this issue.

Change-Id: I497c8b2c1dc548e678698474d3604664cf8eeb07
"}]
commit_message:
Throw TypeError in repository enable/disable macros

Currently we do not validate the type of the reponames argument to the
enable_extra_repos and disable_extra_repos macros. It should be a list,
but we merged a call where the argument was a string, which interpreted
as a list of single characters ('e', 'p', 'e', 'l'), and silently
ignored.

This change validates that the reponames argument is a list to avoid
this issue.

Change-Id: I497c8b2c1dc548e678698474d3604664cf8eeb07

commit_message:
Switch to native Zuul v3 publish job

Use new Zuul v3 publish-openstack-stackviz-element job for periodic
pipeline to publish the tarball.

The job still publishes to
https://tarballs.opendev.org/openstack/stackviz/dist/ and generates same
content (just different paths).

Move the job from periodic to post, there's no need for a daily update.

Remove old job and its playbooks, they are not needed anymore.

Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/710756
Change-Id: I522e1b5e6158e5811578e24a380ce00001a6d40e

subject: Allow usage of assert_called_once method in unit tests
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1131, 'name': 'Brian Haley', 'email': 'haleyb.dev@gmail.com', 'username': 'brian-haley'}, {'_account_id': 11975, 'name': 'Slawek Kaplonski', 'email': 'skaplons@redhat.com', 'username': 'slaweq'}, {'_account_id': 14232, 'name': 'Igor Malinovskiy', 'email': 'u.glide@gmail.com', 'username': 'imalinovskiy'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26622, 'name': 'Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI', 'email': 'neutron_hyperv_ci@cloudbasesolutions.com', 'username': 'neutron_hyperv_ci'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 14232, 'date': '2020-03-02 12:18:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2020-03-02 14:13:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/710753/1 : SUCCESS in 1h 54m 50s'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2020-03-02 19:06:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

This in the unittest.mock library:

https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.mock.html#unittest.mock.Mock.assert_called_once

Since this wasn't allowed before, there are a number of calls like this:

self.assertEqual(1, foo.call_count)

I guess we can just leave those alone and allow this new syntax going forward."}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2020-03-02 22:00:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2020-03-02 23:18:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

Hmm, I guess I didn't notice that neutron still uses the mock library, not unittests.mock, so I don't think we should merge this yet.  Someone can correct me if I'm wrong."}, {'account_id': 14232, 'date': '2020-03-03 08:30:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Mock library from pypi is just a copy of unittests.mock which is provided for backward compatibility:
https://github.com/testing-cabal/mock/blob/8c6dcdfa9d44038202194ef2c3e5ae088089d65a/mock/mock.py#L208

So it's safe to merge this change."}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2020-03-03 15:32:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Igor - thanks for checking, panicked last night and didn't have time to look further"}]

mock.assert_called_once is valid method since Python 3.6
but it's not allowed to use it in neutron because of
outdated flake8 check.

Change-Id: I8cdcc0e32618613472139ad9094bb19d562d6426
"}]
commit_message:
Allow usage of assert_called_once method in unit tests

mock.assert_called_once is valid method since Python 3.6
but it's not allowed to use it in neutron because of
outdated flake8 check.

Change-Id: I8cdcc0e32618613472139ad9094bb19d562d6426

subject: Fix error handling in network trunks operations
messages: [{'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2020-03-03 13:10:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-03-03 14:34:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2020-03-03 14:40:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1\n\nThanks, I somehow managed to miss it when comparing master and stable/train. Another nice one to have for user-friendliness'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-03-03 15:30:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-03 13:10:42.000000000', 'message': "Fix error handling in network trunks operations

It seems like operations defined in network.v2.trunk had no error
handling or even ignored results from Neutron altogether. This meant
that user was not able to say if his requests were successful or not.

This commit fixes the issues by adding error handling through
exceptions.raise_from_response and making sure that Trunk's body is
updated with the actual result from Neutron instead of the info passed
from user (seems like delete_subports() even updated the Trunk object
actually *adding* the removed subports).

Change-Id: Ia2f469690023e1d7e1c1e7935d6681a87f9433cd
Story: #2007239
Task: #38579
(cherry picked from commit 9b7e02bebcb27cb916d6b46eed48a8e1edeadea8)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix error handling in network trunks operations

It seems like operations defined in network.v2.trunk had no error
handling or even ignored results from Neutron altogether. This meant
that user was not able to say if his requests were successful or not.

This commit fixes the issues by adding error handling through
exceptions.raise_from_response and making sure that Trunk's body is
updated with the actual result from Neutron instead of the info passed
from user (seems like delete_subports() even updated the Trunk object
actually *adding* the removed subports).

Change-Id: Ia2f469690023e1d7e1c1e7935d6681a87f9433cd
Story: #2007239
Task: #38579
(cherry picked from commit 9b7e02bebcb27cb916d6b46eed48a8e1edeadea8)

commit_message:
Include user_id attribute in volume information

The v2 and v3 apis return a "user_id" attribute in the detail
response, but this was missing from the corresponding classes.

Change-Id: I3714f6dad7af0bb3a8e818f2e4afd52228d02948

commit_message:
[docs] Change CoreOS URLs to Centos URLs fir IPA

The ironic-python-agent coreos images are unsupported and are
anticipated to be removed from the tarballs.openstack.org site.

In advance of this, we need to remove references to these images.

Change-Id: Ifb402418d7962cf507b190e028a59b94ad5d46ac
(cherry picked from commit baadf62635f64a1f5b87c3b71c16d97c662253e5)

I also don't see any indication of whether the time strings accepted by this API can include TZ information, or at least "Z" indicating that the time is specified in UTC.

I think we should develop support for this in cinderclient at the same time, and not merge this patch without that, so we can ensure all of the details are being handled properly.'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2018-03-14 14:16:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 56:

'}, {'created': '2017-05-03 06:11:34.000000000', 'message': 'Support to query volume filter by changes since/before

Support users can query resources by specifying the time
that resources are changed since or before, and cinder will
return the all which matches condition.

APIImpact
Add two filters changes-since and changes-before in querying API.
"volumes/detail?changes-since=2016-01-01T01:00:00&changes-before=2016-12-31T01:00:00"

NOTE: Now some project have supported this funcation, after finding out
what term they're using, here is the result:

changes-since: nova、glance v1、manila、ceilometer
changed-since: neutron

So for keeping consistent with most of projects, Cinder considers to
use changes-since and changes-before too.

DocImpact

Co-Authored-By: wangxiyuan <wangxiyuan@huawei.com>
'}, {'created': '2017-05-25 04:11:13.000000000', 'message': 'Support to query volume filter by changes since/before

Support users can query resources by specifying the time
that resources are changed since or before, and cinder will
return the all which matches condition.

APIImpact
Add two filters changes-since and changes-before in querying API.
"volumes/detail?changes-since=2016-01-01T01:00:00&changes-before=2016-12-31T01:00:00"

NOTE: Now some project have supported this funcation, after finding out
what term they're using, here is the result:

changes-since: nova, glance(for api v2, it's only mentioned in spec)
changed-since: neutron

So for keeping consistent with most of projects, Cinder considers to
use changes-since and changes-before too.

DocImpact

'}, {'created': '2018-08-14 08:42:24.000000000', 'message': 'Support to query volume filter by changes since/before

Support users can query resources by specifying the time
that resources are changed since or before, and cinder will
return all which match the condition.

The date and time stamp format is ISO 8601: CCYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss±hh:mm.
The ±hh:mm value, if included, returns the time zone as an offset from UTC.

Add two filters changes-since and changes-before in querying API.
"volumes/detail?changes-since=2016-01-01T01:00:00&changes-before=2016-12-31T01:00:00"

NOTE: Now some project have supported this funcation, after finding out
what term they're using, here is the result:

changes-since: nova, glance(for api v2, it's only mentioned in spec)
changed-since: neutron

So for keeping consistent with most of projects, Cinder considers to
use changes-since and changes-before too.

Change-Id: I1f43c37c2266e43146637beadc027ccf6dec017e
Partial-Implements: blueprint support-to-query-cinder-resources-filter-by-change-since
Co-Authored-By: wangxiyuan <wangxiyuan@huawei.com>

that resources are changed since or before, and cinder will
return all which match the condition.

The date and time stamp format is ISO 8601: CCYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss±hh:mm.
The ±hh:mm value, if included, returns the time zone as an offset from UTC.

Add two filters changes-since and changes-before in querying API.
"volumes/detail?changes-since=2016-01-01T01:00:00&changes-before=2016-12-31T01:00:00"

NOTE: Now some project have supported this function, after finding out
what term they're using, here is the result:

changes-since: nova, glance(for api v2, it's only mentioned in spec)
changed-since: neutron

So for keeping consistent with most of projects, Cinder considers to
use changes-since and changes-before too.

Change-Id: I1f43c37c2266e43146637beadc027ccf6dec017e
Partial-Implements: blueprint support-to-query-cinder-resources-filter-by-change-since
Co-Authored-By: wangxiyuan <wangxiyuan@huawei.com>

Add two filters updated_at and created_at in querying API.
"volumes/detail?created_at=gt:2016-01-01T01:00:00,lt:2016-12-31T01:00:00"

commit_message:
Support to query volume filter by updated_at/created_at

Support users can query resources by specifying the time
that resources are created at or updated at with time
comparison operators: "gt/gte/eq/neq/lt/lte",
and cinder will return all which match the condition.

The date and time stamp format is ISO 8601: CCYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss±hh:mm.
The ±hh:mm value, if included, returns the time zone as an offset from UTC.

Add two filters updated_at and created_at in querying API.
"volumes/detail?created_at=gt:2016-01-01T01:00:00,lt:2016-12-31T01:00:00"

Change-Id: I1f43c37c2266e43146637beadc027ccf6dec017e
Partial-Implements: blueprint support-to-query-cinder-resources-filter-by-time-comparison-operators
Co-Authored-By: wangxiyuan <wangxiyuan@huawei.com>

commit_message:
Update the minversion parameter.

Update the minversion parameter to use the python -m pip to install
python packages:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/changelog.html#id185

It's recommend to use this. Remove the useless install_command
parameter.

Change-Id: Idfc08651ce699fbf5800c8a427aeb4c607dd39d7

subject: Clean up concurrent get requests once we have a response
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-02-06 18:44:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-02-06 20:26:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Can you elaborate what exactly we're trying to solve here?  Do we think closing the connection early is primarily beneficial to the proxy or the remote service?"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-02-06 22:15:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I'm mainly worried about the proxy -- it may help out the backend server, too (assuming it can tell that the other side hung up), but that'd just be gravy.

I've been running down an issue where an (apparently overloaded) container server is popping node_timeouts across all proxies. I'm also seeing a spike in object GET latencies that seems to correlate quite nicely with spikes in container listings. My working theory is that the added resource usage of having each proxy waiting on an extra ~500 container requests (over a couple minute window) is what's causing the latency spikes."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-02-06 22:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2020-02-12 05:58:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

> I've been running down an issue where an (apparently overloaded)
 > container server is popping node_timeouts across all proxies. (...)

This answer and the comment you made in-line about the testbed need to go into the changelog."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-03-02 19:33:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-03-02 23:54:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-03-03 16:12:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

I have not been able to demonstrate any objective benefit of this change.  I think you have to have concurrent_gets turned on to have any behavioral difference at all.

I certainly agree with the analysis that the spawned greenthread connections that don't finish first will run to completion in the background after the proxy has already responded to the client and both connections remain open.  So some argument could be mounted there's a virtue of cleanliness in "handling" the connections we won't need to respond - but I've not been able to verify the abrupt termination is cleaner.

I'm introducing delay into a working container server directly:

    diff --git a/swift/container/server.py b/swift/container/server.py
    index 5d89ec4f8..e93d06e81 100644
    --- a/swift/container/server.py
    +++ b/swift/container/server.py
    @@ -847,6 +847,9 @@ class ContainerController(BaseStorageServer):
             return HTTPNoContent(request=req)
     
         def __call__(self, env, start_response):
    +        import random, eventlet
    +        if random.random() < 0.2:
    +            eventlet.sleep(21)
             start_time = time.time()
             req = Request(env)
             self.logger.txn_id = req.headers.get('x-trans-id', None)

The primary difference may then be that none of my tcp or http protocols are violated - these are slow, but working connections and valid responses.

My counts of TCP connections in TIME_WAIT immediately after a burst of container GETs is the same with or without the patch.  I assume this is because of the tcp_tw setttings that prefer keeping working tcp connections to the backend lively which reduces delays "connecting" to backend servers in subsequent requests.

The number of backend responses that log after the client responses finish is the same before or after this change.  I assume this is because no amount of closing the connection on the proxy is going to trick the container server into not finishing and attempting to send it's response - we just push the problem of draining the response into the tcp buffer handling.

The biggest change I notice is the lack of errors in my logs when my servers are slow.  Instead of seeing the proxy log that it timed out a slow response from a backend server - I just see instead silence.  I don't get a log message a request was made.  I don't get a log message the request timedout.  I see the successful response to the client (maybe with an invisible concurrency_timeout delay) then I see the message from the backend server after it finishes.  This change in logging feels worse to me than what we get now.

Aside from some loss of visibility into the logs, I'm also sure that we're loosing error limiting and timing tracking that we were getting by letting the responses finish or timeout so we can annotate the node timing/errors accurately.  This may in fact lead to WORSE aggregate performance with this patch in place by making additional requests to already slow nodes and waiting on connections to downed nodes.  This effect would be most problematic with a concurrency_timeout that's less than your connect_timeout which is fairly common for latency sensitive deployments.

Perhaps more justification could be made for the benefit of this change (i.e. I'm under valuing optimization of proxy CPU against other tradeoffs), or my perception of the neutral and/or negative effects might be mitigated.  I don't have a strong opinion that it should or should not merge - but I'd lean not.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2020-03-03 17:22:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> My counts of TCP connections in TIME_WAIT immediately after a burst
 > of container GETs is the same with or without the patch.

Those worry me a lot for a couple of reasons.

First, I have a bug outstanding in RHOS right now about this.
It turned out that our replicators can consume more sockets
than proxies, if traffic is light, and they easily eat all
the free sockets in PACO clusters.

Second, it appears that kernel people took a course on
removing all the tcp_tw_xxxx tunables. Now, kernel finds out
which sockets to reuse, and there's nothing you can do about it.
In addition, you can have 60,000 TIME_WAIT sockets, yet once
you go and bind or connect, the operation succeeds, because
kernel finds which TIME_WAIT socket to victimize, closes it,
and reuses it. Bottom line, the output of netstat does not
tell you anymore if there's a problem of not enough sockets.
I know they had their reasons, but IMHO this sucks."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-06 18:44:29.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up concurrent get requests once we have a response

Change-Id: I1629075630036af650fbec49efee990a3b1c7090
'}, {'created': '2020-03-02 19:33:44.000000000', 'message': "Clean up concurrent get requests once we have a response

I've been running down an issue where an (apparently overloaded)
container server is popping node_timeouts across all proxies. I'm
*also* seeing a spike in object GET latencies that seems to correlate
quite nicely with spikes in container listings.

My working theory is that the added resource usage of having each
proxy waiting on an extra ~500 container requests (over a couple
minute window) is what's causing the latency spikes.

Let's at least clean up the proxy-server connections and greenthreads
when they're no longer necessary; depending on whether it's started
processing the requests or not, this may also provide some relief to
the overwhelmed container-server.

Here's my testing setup:

 * Create a new, empty container.
 * Stop all container-servers, then restart just *one* of them.
 * Run ncat on one or more of the stopped-container-server ports to
   simulate a hung server; something like

   ncat -lk --max-conns 1024 localhost 6031 >/dev/null

In one window, watch the open connections like

   watch -n .1 'lsof -i TCP | grep 6031'

In another, restart proxies (to make sure nothing's error-limited)
and issue a bunch of requests like

   swift-init proxy restart && ( for i in {1..100}; do curl http://saio:8090/v1/AUTH_test/c >&2 & done; wait ) 2> /dev/null

(You can repeat this last step a few times, see whether your
observation was a one-off or repeatable thing.)

Once it all joins up again, check for open connections and check
the logs for timeouts.

Change-Id: I1629075630036af650fbec49efee990a3b1c7090
"}]
commit_message:
Clean up concurrent get requests once we have a response

I've been running down an issue where an (apparently overloaded)
container server is popping node_timeouts across all proxies. I'm
*also* seeing a spike in object GET latencies that seems to correlate
quite nicely with spikes in container listings.

My working theory is that the added resource usage of having each
proxy waiting on an extra ~500 container requests (over a couple
minute window) is what's causing the latency spikes.

Let's at least clean up the proxy-server connections and greenthreads
when they're no longer necessary; depending on whether it's started
processing the requests or not, this may also provide some relief to
the overwhelmed container-server.

Here's my testing setup:

 * Create a new, empty container.
 * Stop all container-servers, then restart just *one* of them.
 * Run ncat on one or more of the stopped-container-server ports to
   simulate a hung server; something like

   ncat -lk --max-conns 1024 localhost 6031 >/dev/null

In one window, watch the open connections like

   watch -n .1 'lsof -i TCP | grep 6031'

In another, restart proxies (to make sure nothing's error-limited)
and issue a bunch of requests like

   swift-init proxy restart && ( for i in {1..100}; do curl http://saio:8090/v1/AUTH_test/c >&2 & done; wait ) 2> /dev/null

(You can repeat this last step a few times, see whether your
observation was a one-off or repeatable thing.)

Once it all joins up again, check for open connections and check
the logs for timeouts.

Change-Id: I1629075630036af650fbec49efee990a3b1c7090

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

patrole is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: Ied5cfb29363401d713c21fc579f30e1ef9c1210f

commit_message:
devstack: support lib/neutron

Support both legacy and current service naming in plugin
Use neutron_service_plugin_class_add function
Use new names in gate configuration
Remove config files from neutron-db-manage call

Also update CI configuration files location (we have them in tree now)

Change-Id: I76d13c6834d9da12fb372140f0c76758cbeb415d
(cherry picked from commit 94a8952655996b3cb8ad25f55f270938f6fb333d)

Done'}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2020-02-25 12:33:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2020-02-25 12:46:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

In existing deployments it would require migrating to the new Kafka topic name. Renaming topics is not supported so we'd have to delete and create new one. How do we feel about that?

I understand that the proposed name better describes the purpose of the topic and avoids the conflict with the topic for persisting events collected by events API endpoint."}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2020-02-25 12:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2020-02-25 12:49:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2020-02-25 12:51:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2020-02-25 12:59:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > In existing deployments it would require migrating to the new Kafka
 > topic name. Renaming topics is not supported so we'd have to delete
 > and create new one. How do we feel about that?
 > 
 > I understand that the proposed name better describes the purpose of
 > the topic and avoids the conflict with the topic for persisting
 > events collected by events API endpoint.

In existing deployments user can decide to use old name, user can change this name in configuration file."}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2020-02-25 13:05:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2020-02-25 13:15:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2020-02-25 13:47:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

Thanks Adrian. I understand the motivation. I think this change needs to have a clearly documented path for migrating to the new topic name if we are to consider merging it. I think it will be difficult to document such a path without risking service interuption.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2020-02-25 14:16:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Hmm, I agree the naming should make it clear, and would like to make the topic names clear as to their purpose, maybe alarm_events_topic and openstack_events_topic (for the events api).  But we would need to talk through a few migration scenarios.  If the change happens as part of a disruptive upgrade of Monasca, maybe it would be ok.'}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2020-02-25 15:22:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> Hmm, I agree the naming should make it clear, and would like to
 > make the topic names clear as to their purpose, maybe
 > alarm_events_topic and openstack_events_topic (for the events api).
 >  But we would need to talk through a few migration scenarios.  If
 > the change happens as part of a disruptive upgrade of Monasca,
 > maybe it would be ok.

I like openstack_events_topic name for event pipeline, this name is better then only event_topic and also this should make migration to new alarm event topic easier'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2020-03-03 12:22:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

In general I agree that we should have more meaningful and unambiguous configuration option names and default values. I'm also fine with changing these but we should reduce potential migration problems for operators as much as possible by providing migration documentation.

Also, the implementation should be done in a way to allow operators to keep their existing set up."}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2020-03-03 12:26:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

`openstack_events_topic` seems to me to be too narrow. We have an API which is capable of accepting events from various sources, not just OpenStack. Perhaps something like `collected_events`?'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2020-03-03 16:46:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

> `openstack_events_topic` seems to me to be too narrow. We have an
 > API which is capable of accepting events from various sources, not
 > just OpenStack. Perhaps something like `collected_events`?

That does have a nice sound.'}]

commit_message:
Change name of topic used to send alarm and alarm def events

Change this name from events_topic to alarms_events_topic,
in further events_topic will be use for event pipeline

Story: 2003881
Task: 38861

Change-Id: If49bf24b2b24215f5e4af84d93590899b6a93f26

commit_message:
[docs] Change CoreOS URLs to Centos URLs fir IPA

The ironic-python-agent coreos images are unsupported and are
anticipated to be removed from the tarballs.openstack.org site.

In advance of this, we need to remove references to these images.

Change-Id: Ifb402418d7962cf507b190e028a59b94ad5d46ac

subject: Remove stestr from requirements.txt
messages:
[{'account_id': 26775, 'date': '2018-11-06 11:01:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-11-06 17:28:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'm not sure we should do this. In the past projects could rely on oslotest to pull in the correct test runner. I don't know whether that was used as part of the stestr migration, but this could be a breaking change for consuming projects and there isn't a lot of benefit to it. Most everyone using oslotest should be using stestr anyway."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 14:48:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I personally think this is worth the risk. A quick look through codesearch.o.o suggests everyone using oslotest in requirements.txt is also including oslotest, and if they're not they should be. Perhaps we could use a major version bump if we were really nervous?"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-12-18 22:08:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

> I personally think this is worth the risk. A quick look through
 > codesearch.o.o suggests everyone using oslotest in requirements.txt
 > is also including oslotest, and if they're not they should be.
 > Perhaps we could use a major version bump if we were really
 > nervous?

I assume you mean they're also including stestr? If so then I'm okay with this."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-01-20 17:13:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2020-01-21 10:44:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-03-03 14:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

it broke stackviz at least - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/710915/2

not sure if any other repo faces the same issue. I think it will be good to send this to ML about explicitly add stestr as their dependencies.

ML before this merged could be better trigger,'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2020-03-03 16:04:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We did look to see if projects using oslotest were already requiring stestr. It appears we missed one, but we didn't merge this without considering the impacts.

I'll send a quick email to the list too just in case anyone else is affected though."}]

'}]

commit_message:
Add serviceaccountname to daemonset list

This change fixes the gate failing due to a recent change to allow
making more sections of the daemonset overridable.

Change-Id: I7f5e587d03c3c305d10011718edaeebfa947a04e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-13 08:35:13.000000000', 'message': "Send a separate bind event to Nova for each ARQ in an instance.

This is based on discussion with Nova community. See:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692707/6/nova/objects/external_event.py@36

Each event has a unique tag, i.e. the ARQ UUID, and the
bind status for that ARQ.

Each ARQ has its own state. However, the bind status sent to Nova
should be 'completed' or 'failed'. The logic to do that conversion
should not be in nova_client.py, to keep it free of ARQ state details.
So it has been added in get_arq_bind_status() in ext_arq_job.py.

Change-Id: Iddbf9a77196fc42ac82ad1f6d88a4b0732852463

commit_message:
Send a separate bind event to Nova for each ARQ in an instance.

This is based on discussion with Nova community. See:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692707/6/nova/objects/external_event.py@36

Each event has a unique tag, i.e. the ARQ UUID, and the
bind status for that ARQ.

Each ARQ has its own state. However, the bind status sent to Nova
should be 'completed' or 'failed'. The logic to do that conversion
should not be in nova_client.py, to keep it free of ARQ state details.
So it has been added in get_arq_bind_status() in ext_arq_job.py.

Change-Id: Iddbf9a77196fc42ac82ad1f6d88a4b0732852463

commit_message:
Move rejection of min-bw rule on non-physnet port to the ovs qos driver

The ovs qos driver only supports the min-bw rule on physnet ports.
However other (future) qos drivers may support the min-bw rule on
non-physnet ports too, therefore implementing the rejection of the
unsupported combination in the qos plugin was a bug.

This change moves the rejection from the qos plugin to the ovs qos
driver.

Change-Id: I02d77a03c411dc8ab303a7d7b53d7ea93cc9f4c6
Closes-Bug: #1861442
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/705694
Related-Bug: #1819029

subject: Use InfluxDB default [http]/max-row-limit setting
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-03 12:18:14.000000000', 'message': 'Use InfluxDB default [http]/max-row-limit setting

Since version 1.2.2, InfluxDB uses 0 (unlimited) as default value for
[http]/max-row-limit [1].

Using the default value resolves an issue with the CloudKitty v1 API
returning only 10000 dataframes.

[1] https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v1.7/about_the_project/releasenotes-changelog/#v1-2-2-2017-03-14

Change-Id: I6eb8c1216e3a9295b7d8cb7fbcbb8778ae7caf7e
Closes-Bug: #1862358
(cherry picked from commit fc3492bcb18e74cb76753da46fd4ad0bb098b6bd)
(cherry picked from commit 349febd88af09ac217f6025cc946508bd69652bc)
'}]
commit_message:
Use InfluxDB default [http]/max-row-limit setting

Since version 1.2.2, InfluxDB uses 0 (unlimited) as default value for
[http]/max-row-limit [1].

Using the default value resolves an issue with the CloudKitty v1 API
returning only 10000 dataframes.

[1] https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v1.7/about_the_project/releasenotes-changelog/#v1-2-2-2017-03-14

Change-Id: I6eb8c1216e3a9295b7d8cb7fbcbb8778ae7caf7e
Closes-Bug: #1862358
(cherry picked from commit fc3492bcb18e74cb76753da46fd4ad0bb098b6bd)
(cherry picked from commit 349febd88af09ac217f6025cc946508bd69652bc)

commit_message:
Require stestr

The python 3.6 and newer tests fail since they don't install stestr, add
explicit requirement.

Since https://review.opendev.org/615826/ oslotest does not have stestr
in requirements, so it needs to be added explicitely.

Change-Id: I069a27a2abd2b1a12ea0c58b38c4445e1fc79793

commit_message:
Document how an undercloud can be cleaned-up

This procedure has been tested on Train and onward and aims to be for
devs, although it's enough for any undercloud to be cleaned-up and
re-installed later.

Change-Id: I7dc7f2903f9a624cf8b4032606652113245b88a8

Following I21dd51c82534704f31ca8d3f72cb2587ee216cd9, the test inventory
was synced with the multinode inventory. This removed some temporary
ceph groups used by the ceph-ansible-upgrade jobs, and broke them. This

commit_message:
CI: Add Ceph groups back to inventory

Following I21dd51c82534704f31ca8d3f72cb2587ee216cd9, the test inventory
was synced with the multinode inventory. This removed some temporary
ceph groups used by the ceph-ansible-upgrade jobs, and broke them. This
change adds the groups back.

Change-Id: I37379258447ffde6b083f4e8d9a1644bc17cd165

commit_message:
Sync neutron-ml2-ansible.yaml files

The two files have different contents. Using the one in the services sub
as the source of truth and making them the same.

That's exactly why we are asking you the feedback :)"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-02-29 05:08:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-02-29 14:27:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-02-29 14:46:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-03-02 10:00:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-03-03 08:44:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

So I'm giving my PTL approve since we found out that we won't need new official releases out of  stable/rocky. If we still can backport patches into it, it is totally fine. Then we'll be able to build RPMs, if needed."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-03-03 13:45:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

> So I'm giving my PTL approve since we found out that we won't need
 > new official releases out of  stable/rocky. If we still can
 > backport patches into it, it is totally fine. Then we'll be able to
 > build RPMs, if needed.

Yep, definitely. The hope with Extended Maintenance is that patches will still be backported. Our old policy was to tag and delete the branch, preventing any further work from happening. This is a compromise to be able to still get those bugfixes backported so anyone downstream can pick them up, just no more official releases coming out of the community.

Thanks!"}]

commit_message:
[mistral] Transition Rocky to EM

This transition the rocky branch to extended maintenance.
Changes for bugfixes and things the team deems important are
still encouraged, but there will no longer be official releases
off of the branch.

Please +1 if the team is ready for us to proceed with this
transition, or -1 if there are any final backports currently in
flight that we should wait for. For the latter case, please
update the patch with the new commit hash after doing a final
release to get those changes out so we know to proceed with the
transition.

Change-Id: I63e6a036dbf533201724749275a84b69bdd296cb
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add alternative local_interface for centos-8 undercloud OVB

On centos-8 nodes, the local_interface is name differently.
It is not eth1. Current testing shows it to be ens6
on rdocloud.

Change-Id: If741bc4052da9766239a372d4dc89a2d7cd0e7d0

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-30 17:38:19.000000000', 'message': "Fix error handling in network trunks operations

It seems like operations defined in network.v2.trunk had no error
handling or even ignored results from Neutron altogether. This meant
that user was not able to say if his requests were successful or not.

This commit fixes the issues by adding error handling through
exceptions.raise_from_response and making sure that Trunk's body is
updated with the actual result from Neutron instead of the info passed
from user (seems like delete_subports() even updated the Trunk object
actually *adding* the removed subports).

Change-Id: Ia2f469690023e1d7e1c1e7935d6681a87f9433cd
Story: #2007239
Task: #38579
"}]
commit_message:
Fix error handling in network trunks operations

It seems like operations defined in network.v2.trunk had no error
handling or even ignored results from Neutron altogether. This meant
that user was not able to say if his requests were successful or not.

This commit fixes the issues by adding error handling through
exceptions.raise_from_response and making sure that Trunk's body is
updated with the actual result from Neutron instead of the info passed
from user (seems like delete_subports() even updated the Trunk object
actually *adding* the removed subports).

Change-Id: Ia2f469690023e1d7e1c1e7935d6681a87f9433cd
Story: #2007239
Task: #38579

subject: Use InfluxDB default [http]/max-row-limit setting
messages: [{'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2020-03-02 20:56:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-03-03 07:55:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-03 10:25:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-02 20:56:52.000000000', 'message': 'Use InfluxDB default [http]/max-row-limit setting

Since version 1.2.2, InfluxDB uses 0 (unlimited) as default value for
[http]/max-row-limit [1].

Using the default value resolves an issue with the CloudKitty v1 API
returning only 10000 dataframes.

[1] https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v1.7/about_the_project/releasenotes-changelog/#v1-2-2-2017-03-14

Change-Id: I6eb8c1216e3a9295b7d8cb7fbcbb8778ae7caf7e
Closes-Bug: #1862358
(cherry picked from commit fc3492bcb18e74cb76753da46fd4ad0bb098b6bd)
'}]
commit_message:
Use InfluxDB default [http]/max-row-limit setting

Since version 1.2.2, InfluxDB uses 0 (unlimited) as default value for
[http]/max-row-limit [1].

Using the default value resolves an issue with the CloudKitty v1 API
returning only 10000 dataframes.

[1] https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v1.7/about_the_project/releasenotes-changelog/#v1-2-2-2017-03-14

Change-Id: I6eb8c1216e3a9295b7d8cb7fbcbb8778ae7caf7e
Closes-Bug: #1862358
(cherry picked from commit fc3492bcb18e74cb76753da46fd4ad0bb098b6bd)

commit_message:
Configurable logrotate rotation interval and count

The logrotate rotation interval and count are not configurable.
Currently, the configuration is a "default" that keeps 6 weeks of logs.

Change-Id: I4f55ee2a98f7861cb8de2724f5edc32da6d2f9ee

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-28 10:07:47.000000000', 'message': '[Stein only] Improve ceph services discovery.

In the upgrade from Rocky to Stein we are required to run
an extra step to migrate the ceph systemd unit files to
work with podman instead of Docker. To know which roles
need this step to be run, this patch improves a little
bit the logic by storing in a enabled_services fact all
the services enabled per role. This allows us to check
later, when creating the templates, if the role we are
creating the templates for has ceph enabled or not.

Change-Id: I5f4a92587ae5862219f3949bff2f83debf634c5c
'}, {'created': '2020-02-28 10:31:14.000000000', 'message': 'Improve ceph services discovery.

In the upgrade from Rocky to Stein we are required to run
an extra step to migrate the ceph systemd unit files to
work with podman instead of Docker. To know which roles
need this step to be run, this patch improves a little
bit the logic by storing in a enabled_services fact all
the services enabled per role. This allows us to check
later, when creating the templates, if the role we are
creating the templates for has ceph enabled or not.

This change is also useful for the FFWD upgrade from 13
to 16, as the workflow will be almost the same.

Change-Id: I5f4a92587ae5862219f3949bff2f83debf634c5c
'}]
commit_message:
Improve ceph services discovery.

In the upgrade from Rocky to Stein we are required to run
an extra step to migrate the ceph systemd unit files to
work with podman instead of Docker. To know which roles
need this step to be run, this patch improves a little
bit the logic by storing in a enabled_services fact all
the services enabled per role. This allows us to check
later, when creating the templates, if the role we are
creating the templates for has ceph enabled or not.

This change is also useful for the FFWD upgrade from 13
to 16, as the workflow will be almost the same.

Change-Id: I5f4a92587ae5862219f3949bff2f83debf634c5c

Change-Id: I6fb5bc78629fcccb9242ec014d26b2f24114b8a7

commit_message:
Revert "Force facts cache refreshing before upgrade."

It was seeing that this patch does not help solving the bug
https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1856313. However Ia1fa60c22e482ab14a509730cf93634772e077a7 has been
tested and ensures having the right cache content when running the upgrade tasks. No need to revert this patch in master as these tasks are not present there anymore.

This reverts commit f632ea38ac1f5c68d0659d5a8d0fb51bf7844eb4.

Change-Id: I6fb5bc78629fcccb9242ec014d26b2f24114b8a7

commit_message:
WIP [DNM]: POC to run paunch containers for FFWD2.

Due to the workflow of the upgrade from Queens to Stein, in
which an operating system is also performed. We are required
to run the upgrade tasks (db syncs, online migrations, etc...)
between the docker_config steps.
Leveraging the existing of a paunch interface which allows us
overriding config values, we can run via pure Ansible the needed
steps to achieve those migrations.

Co-Authored-By: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovat@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Iadc7ff459f3aea97a0d1ba1c11b0cd9c27d7fff7

[{'created': '2019-12-16 15:30:48.000000000', 'message': "[DNM] Change cirros image used for tests

While checking bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1856523
we found that potentially problem is in cirros.
This patch uses modified cirros image that has removed '--silent'
from CURL.

Change-Id: Id56b3dec76ce130bae58e590a859e576f4ab2f64
"}]
commit_message:
[DNM] Change cirros image used for tests

While checking bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1856523
we found that potentially problem is in cirros.
This patch uses modified cirros image that has removed '--silent'
from CURL.

Change-Id: Id56b3dec76ce130bae58e590a859e576f4ab2f64

commit_message:
Add VRRP failover test

The aim of the test is to validate that in case master VM becomes not
available the traffic to the VIP is directed to the second VM.
Such scenario is often used for example in environments with Octavia
load balancers.

Scenario:
- Create a port for VRRP VIP and ports for VMs with
  allowed address pair configured to the VIP IP
- Create two VMs on different compute nodes
- Setup VRRP between the VMs
- Test traffic to virtual IP (login via ssh)
- Shut off active VM
- Test traffic to virtual IP. Traffic should now flow to the second VM

Change-Id: Ib2f141776d43cf78164e03e0c53ad0a156b565fb

commit_message:
Fix incorrect usage of assertRaisesRegex in unit tests

This test passes None instead of a callable, which just happens to
work in Python < 3.9 and breaks in 3.9. Since SessionTimeout is not
actually required, I'm removing the wrong unit test.

Change-Id: I64db7482c4879950dee2b020033d4d1101f61bb6

commit_message:
filters: make get_domain_id more robust

- Return None if no domain name was given
- Raise a KeyError if the domain name wasn't found so lookup couldn't
  happen.

Change-Id: Iec0009eab5ae33b9dda1ffbabc9fbfc83b2c5909

commit_message:
Check ingress and egress IPBlock rules for NP

Create 4 pods
Check that the http connection works before applying NP rules
Apply NP by allowing all and blocking pod1 ingress and pod2 egress
Check that http connection from pod1 to pod4 is blocked
Check that http connection from pod4 to pod2 is blocked
Check that http connection from pod4 to pod3 is still working

Change-Id: Ida893c0ca6a340b342d903974ec64b8a8c98565b

commit_message:
Remove  PYTHONHASHSEED variable from integration tests env

PYTHONHASHSEED for integration tests was added in 2015 to run tests in a
same order each time. Now we don't need this workaround because
integration tests work well in any order they are executed.

Change-Id: Ide019baaf8786da14cc9edcc46b40ab5fabf3ef5

messages: [{'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-02-28 17:24:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch stable/stein.'}, {'account_id': 21757, 'date': '2020-02-29 02:06:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2020-03-02 09:01:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-03-02 11:01:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 21757, 'date': '2020-03-03 06:18:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-28 17:24:01.000000000', 'message': "Fix kolla_toolbox_pip_virtualenv_packages override

backport: train, stein, rocky

Override in filter needs to follow the rule:
<image_name>_<call_type>_<override/append/remove>
`call_type` for `kolla_toolbox_pip_virtualenv_packages` should be
`pip_virtualenv_packages`, and `pip_packages` can't match with
`kolla_toolbox_pip_virtualenv_packages`, this makes
the value can't be overrode in template override.

Change-Id: I1dbe2dfd4bce73ce2285f45f997d45b5dcc95f4c
Closes-bug: #1865119
(cherry picked from commit 74d5a66e6bf744ad936d702443a8d64be86441ba)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix kolla_toolbox_pip_virtualenv_packages override

backport: train, stein, rocky

Override in filter needs to follow the rule:
<image_name>_<call_type>_<override/append/remove>
`call_type` for `kolla_toolbox_pip_virtualenv_packages` should be
`pip_virtualenv_packages`, and `pip_packages` can't match with
`kolla_toolbox_pip_virtualenv_packages`, this makes
the value can't be overrode in template override.

Change-Id: I1dbe2dfd4bce73ce2285f45f997d45b5dcc95f4c
Closes-bug: #1865119
(cherry picked from commit 74d5a66e6bf744ad936d702443a8d64be86441ba)

repository and git clone command to be more specific.

[{'created': '2020-03-02 13:48:17.000000000', 'message': 'Replace Docker service by Podman in roles_data.

In Stein Podman passed to be the default containers engine [0].
Therefore, if upgrading from a release which used Docker and
composables roles, we need to replace the Docker service by the
Podman one.

This patch does this replacement in the roles_data file used
for the upgrade prepare.

[0] - Ie9f5d3b6380caa6824ca940ca48ed0fcf6308608

Change-Id: Ic69a78435491d2dbcff80dc0a15098a3c2ebf213
'}]
commit_message:
Replace Docker service by Podman in roles_data.

In Stein Podman passed to be the default containers engine [0].
Therefore, if upgrading from a release which used Docker and
composables roles, we need to replace the Docker service by the
Podman one.

This patch does this replacement in the roles_data file used
for the upgrade prepare.

[0] - Ie9f5d3b6380caa6824ca940ca48ed0fcf6308608

Change-Id: Ic69a78435491d2dbcff80dc0a15098a3c2ebf213

commit_message:
Ensure that default SG exists during list of SG rules API call

During processing of security group rule list API call Neutron will
now ensure that default security group for project given in the filters
or in the context exists.
It is similar to what is done for list of security groups or creation of
new network/port in the project.

Change-Id: Id6fee5a752968b356b884d939b708a420016c9bc
Closes-Bug: #1864171

commit_message:
magnum: Temporarily disable unit tests on SUSE

Some unit tests are failing on the SUSE CI. We do not want that to
block all patches, so let's skip them until we can investigate the
root cause.

Change-Id: I93351fd40abbb763592fe9dff639978bd35fc60c
(cherry picked from commit 14330bb9b464d98b27c8f434341e6e26f8c20051)

commit_message:
Add support for endpoint change notification

Add support for recent changes to keystone to allow consuming
charms to request notification about endpoint changes.

Change-Id: Icacca3445980cdb866cb0dad90b288ce96e8c460
